awd_titl_txt: Microlocal Analysis of Inverse Problems in Electrical Impedance Tomography, Radar, and Seismics
awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns inverse problems, which use mathematical models to describe how measurements of waves, whether electrostatic, electromagnetic or acoustic, in the near field (at the surface of an object) or in the far field (imaging remotely) can be used to nondestructively determine features or physical properties of interest inside or on the object. Such problems are ubiquitous in the modern technological world; the ones in this proposal occur in medical and industrial imaging, radar, and exploration seismology using acoustics. This award will support work on three projects in the area of inverse problems modeled by elliptic and hyperbolic partial differential equations. Progress will lead to improved reconstruction, via nondestructive imaging or remote sensing, of jumps and other singularities in material parameters of interest, such as electrical conductivity, radar reflectivity coefficients, and acoustic sound speeds. Graduate students will be trained in the mathematical techniques needed for this analysis, adding to the STEM workforce with advanced training.

The goal of all three projects is to better understand the interaction between the geometry underlying these inverse problems and the analysis, particularly  microlocal analysis, needed to improve reconstructions. These improvements will follow from a better understanding of the microlocal geometry underlying filtered back-projection methods. The first project will extend work already under way on using complex principal type propagation of singularities to improve the ability of Electrical Impedance Tomography to image inclusions within inclusions. One possible application is to stroke diagnosis; another is detecting defects in manufactured parts. The investigator will both try to refine his earlier work on a two-dimensional model to produce sharper images and extend the approach to the physically significant three-dimensional situation. The second project will develop techniques for controlling the composition of degenerate Fourier integral operators, needed in the study of Doppler Synthetic Aperture Radar, refining and extending the current state of the art. The analysis of linearized full wave inversion in the last project will require decompositions of imaging operators, of Littlewood-Paley type but adapted to the ray geometry of the velocity model, leading to improved seismic imaging algorithms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the research supported by this award was discovering new techniques for controlling the size of quantities that occur across a range of mathematical fields and their applications to other disciplines. Due to their appearance in many problems, progress on how to understand such expressions in one area can potentially be transferred to a completely different one. In this research the areas where they occur ranged from seismic imaging of the subsurface of the Earth to results concerning the existence of rich collections of point configurations in fractal sets.
The expressions in question are multilinear, in the sense that they depend on two or more variables,  and depend simply (linearly) on each one while the other variables are all held fixed. The quantities can be scalars (numbers) or, as in this research,  functions of one or more variables, in which case one speaks of multilinear operators. A typical way that a multilinear operator arises is in imaging, whether by electromagnetic or acoustic waves, where one makes a linear approximation of the scattered wave and wants to know how much of an error is introduced by ignoring the higher order terms, which typically correspond to multiple reflections that the waves experience in encountering the object or region being imaged. In order to ensure that the approximation is a good one, or to understand when it is not, it is essential to control the size of the higher order terms, which are nonlinear or multilinear expressions.

In this work,  both the linearization themselves and multilinear, or at least bilinear, correction terms were studied. The former were analyzed in the context of seismic imaging using borehole data, i.e., using arrays of acoustic receivers located in a well to detect sound waves stimulated by acoustic sources located either on the surface or in a second well. Borehole data is used for a variety of purposes, including in search of hydrocarbon reserves or sites for carbon sequestration, as well as monitoring of pollution plumes underground. The research supported by this award characterized the location and strength  of imaging artifacts, i.e., features in the images that should not be there. It was shown that for several combination of data acquisition and acoustic ray geometries, the artifacts are strong and non removable, while in others  artifacts are either absent or relatively weak.

Progress was also made on understanding the higher order correction terms that result from linearized seismic imaging, in a generality that includes borehole data but also data resulting from more conventional seismic prospecting, where both the sources and receivers are on the surface.

The NSF Intellectual Merit criteria were met by the contribution of fundamental mathematical understanding of the linear (oscillatory integral and Fourier integral) operator theory that allowed for precise description of the artifacts in seismic imaging, as well as the multilinear operator theory used in the study of higher order correction terms and in the analysis of point configurations. The cross-fertilization between these projects will contribute to further developments in these areas. The Broader Impacts criteria were met by the potential application of some of these projects to real-world problems such as carbon sequestration site location and pollution monitoring. In addition, a Ph.D. student was trained in these techniques and is joining the STEM workforce.
